text:
I personally keep quite an open mind about anything presented, written, broadcast by other people whatever their background or intentions. Obviously every book, paper, course is going to vary in value and quality, but I see everything as a “punt” in itself. Is it going to be worth my time reading? Is it going to be worth paying £X? And generally I value things with quite a high potential return on investment. I absolutely know if I didn’t depend on external material by people who haven’t necessarily made big money betting then I wouldn’t have got where I am today.

If something that costs £3,000 allows me to learn one tiny little titbit, or 1% of its overall content gives me some impact, then it’ll likely have been worth way more than £3,000 to me (in my case, partly because of the level I’m betting at). Even if I don’t learn anything specific and it proves to be a source of inspiration or idea generation then it will likely have been worth it. Obviously it’s still a £3k punt. I personally wouldn’t punt £20k on Psychoff’s 1-1, even though there probably is stuff to learn, and probably isn’t worth it for almost everyone. My best bets have obviously been from trading time for free reads or small amounts of money for books, although still 90% I learn nothing from. 

I’d advise really keeping an eye open and watching out for the one bit of info that might significantly impact you positively. 1000-1 shots happen, but at the same time don’t bet £1000 on every shot.

text: What you say is completely valid <@USYQKE5HN> and I particularly agree that anything might be an opportunity for a bit of inspiration but I think there is legitimate concern about the marketing of very expensive material to people who might be described as 'hopefuls'. Will most of the people signing up for this course be seasoned professionals looking for that one tiny insight or bit of inspiration? I suspect not. I don't doubt that the vast bulk of the content is available for free here or elsewhere and most of the rest for the cost of a book. Given that we have so many people now on this channel, most of whom must surely be relative beginners I think it's worth pointing that out. I don't know anything about most of the people involved in this particular course and they do seem a bit more credible than some of what we see, but I can't imagine myself recommending it to anyone, especially if it's going to cost them a months salary.

text: There is plenty of free and cheap materials out there that will do wonders - I noticed <@UBS7QANF3> put up a list of books last week which I owned half of, the other half are now in my wishlist - and I think getting diverse thinking can only help you, but a little Bayesian thinking can help weight inputs. People posting perfect trading positions on twitter and asking for thousands for training and academics who know the theory but don't seem to be interested in the practice tend to go towards one end of the spectrum compared to books and papers written by people with proven tracks records, to my mind

text: I ask myself what it would take to induce me to reveal something that I wouldn't give away for free on here and I struggle to come up with a number. Certainly far more than any of these courses are charging. Maybe the people offering the courses know far more than I do and their threshold for what's secret is higher, or maybe the money just means more to them than it would to me, or maybe they just know that there are people who will pay for information that they could access for nothing and they just think 'why not?'

text: I am not going in for it myself, but I think that a lot of courses are a risky investment - and you only find out if it is worth it after attending. I have been on a couple of courses as part of previous jobs. Both in excess of £3K, both in the area of programming and operating systems and both utterly useless. I think theses things are dependent on the persons skills and experience that they have beforehand - sometimes too much experience can make it as worthless as too little (where your foundations are not strong enough to make the most of it).

text: I'm all for training in general but think one of the differences between offering a course in programming and one in gambling is that you can sell all of your knowledge of code without it diminishing the value of that knowledge to you. The programming trainer is at least incentivised to teach you as much as they can.

text:
For me, a lot of these courses, tipping services, software, etc are targeted at punters who dream of making a living from betting and want a bullet-pointed guide on a single sheet of A5 because they can't be arsed to put the hours in doing research. I also believe that most of the people behind it aren't making anywhere near the sums they claim. The usual argument goes along the lines of "I've made my millions and am now willing to share my secrets" but if that were true, why is there a fee to access this information? For me they fall into three basic categories:

• I have lost thousands in my betting career. Let's sell some snake oil and attempt to recover my losses.
• I was making good money from betting, but now I've lost my edge. Let's sell some snake oil.
• I am now stinking rich and have invested my money wisely, so let's educate others free of charge and enjoy the gift of giving.
Note that all of the above will easily fit on a sheet of A5.

elements.text: For me, a lot of these courses, tipping services, software, etc are targeted at punters who dream of making a living from betting and want a bullet-pointed guide on a single sheet of A5 because they can't be arsed to put the hours in doing research. I also believe that most of the people behind it aren't making anywhere near the sums they claim. The usual argument goes along the lines of "I've made my millions and am now willing to share my secrets" but if that were true, why is there a fee to access this information? For me they fall into three basic categories:
I have lost thousands in my betting career. Let's sell some snake oil and attempt to recover my losses.
I was making good money from betting, but now I've lost my edge. Let's sell some snake oil.
I am now stinking rich and have invested my money wisely, so let's educate others free of charge and enjoy the gift of giving.
Note that all of the above will easily fit on a sheet of A5.

text:
I agree if we are talking about some shithouser like "The Badger" who "trades" allsorts but focuses on teaching IP horse racing traders how to "race read" using video streams delayed by who-knows-how-many-seconds. Now as an inplay botter I recognise that I benefit greatly from scum like him duping newbies with some pisspot e-book and making them think they can make money manually trading inplay against video lag/drones/GPS/tracksiders, but it does not sit comfortably with me at all from a moral perspective.

But now compare the other side of the "courses" coin. Imagine someone teaching a course on multinomial logistic regression to an audience who want to model probabilities of horses in a race using historical data/form etc. Or basic poisson regression so you could implement dixon-coles or some ML technique - specifics don't really matter provided it is an actual subject that the tutor has expertise in. The application area (making money from sports betting) is the selling point but paying to learn the methodology from a quality teacher is by no means "dodgy" even if afterwards the technique does not yield profit. After all you can have the right tools but they might not be good enough unless you have the right data (be that bespoke data or fast stream stuff etc). I think I know the types you are referring to though <@U016TGY3676> and I agree with you for the most part. Nobody with an edge is going to sell it on unless they at stage 3 in your list - and after that point that edge will likely evaporate quickly the more people start to utilise it.
